headline.main: F.D.A. Is Caught Between Demand For New Goods and Public Safety; F.D.A. Caught in the Middle of Conflicting Demands

byline.original: By RICHARD D. LYONS Special to The New York Times

docs.abstract: Article on Westchester County's Consumer Protection Unit; illus (M)
docs.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, March 12 The Food and Drug Administration's ability to assure the safety and usefulness of tens of thousands of household products, has been torn between unending demands for new consumer goods and vastly more sophisticated methods of detecting potential dangers in those products.
docs.snippet: WASHINGTON, March 12 The Food and Drug Administration's ability to assure the safety and usefulness of tens of thousands of household products, has been torn between unending demands for new consumer goods and vastly more sophisticated methods of...

headline.main: SACCHARIN BAN STIRS DEMAND TO CURB F.D.A.; Doctors Say Removal of Artificial Sweetener Could Bring Rise in Heart Disease and Arthritis

byline.original: By BERNARD WEINRAUB Special to The New York Times

docs.abstract: Drs and groups representing diabetics express concern about impact of saccharin ban, contending that removal of saccharin from mkt could lead to increase in obesity, heart disease and arthritis (M)
docs.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, March 11 The Food and Drug Administration's decision to ban the use of saccharin in foods and beverages prompted a Congressional challenge today and demands to curb the powers of the agency.
docs.snippet: WASHINGTON, March 11 The Food and Drug Administration's decision to ban the use of saccharin in foods and beverages prompted a Congressional challenge today and demands to curb the powers of the agency.

headline.main: Personal Health; Breast-Feeding May Help An Infant to a Better Life

docs.abstract: Article on recent survey finding that nearly 40% of Amer mothers now breast feed babies, double percentage 15 yrs ago; reasons for trend discussed; Drs Gerald Gaull, Jane Pitt and Allan S Cunningham comment (L)
docs.snippet: Article on recent survey finding that nearly 40% of Amer mothers now breast feed babies, double percentage 15 yrs ago; reasons for trend discussed; Drs Gerald Gaull, Jane Pitt and Allan S Cunningham comment (L)
